> However a question came up recently that if you specify the
> tests by overriding the runTest() method as below (static
> invocation), that setUp() and tearDown() do not get called
> for every method, but only get called once.

I don't see why on earth you would write a test by overwriting runTest, 
but let's take that as an example.

If you take a look at the TestCase class, you'll notice that it's in 
fact runBare that calls setUp/tearDown:

	public void runBare() throws Throwable {
		setUp();
		try {
			runTest();
		}
		finally {
			tearDown();
		}
	}

runTest is only executing _one single_ method of the TestCase object. 
Creating a TestCase like you do [new MyTest("Testing runTest()")] is 
wrong (in a normal case).  The name passed to the TestCase is originally 
the name of the test method that will be executed.

so you see that overwriting runTest will not prevent the setUp and 
tearDown methods to be invoked.

hth

-Vladimir
